unnormalised: Okay, so you know how everyone's been talking about gut health lately? Well, turns out it's not just a fad. Our gastroenterology dept. at Lifeline Hospital sees cases ranging from simple indigestion to serious stuff like Crohn's every single day. And honestly, a lot of it boils down to lifestyle, stress levels, and, of course, that delicious but often questionable street food we all love.

unnormalised: Speaking of food, I remember this one time we had a patient, Mr. Sharma, who kept complaining of stomach cramps after eating golgappas from a particular vendor near his office. After a bunch of tests, including a colonoscopy (which, btw, costs around Rs. 8000 at many private labs), we found out he had a mild infection. Doc advised him to lay off the street food for a while, and thankfully, he recovered pretty quickly.

unnormalised: But it's not always just about hygiene, ya know? Sometimes, it's genetics. We often see families where multiple members suffer from conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). And managing IBS can be a real challenge! It's all about finding the right diet, managing stress, and sometimes, even needing medications like Mebeverine 200mg.

unnormalised: Then there are the more complex cases like ulcerative colitis (UC). Treating UC often involves a combination of drugs, and in severe instances, surgery might be needed. We had a patient, Aisha, who had been battling UC for years. Her initial diagnosis was made back in 2018, and she's been on and off medication ever since. It's a tough journey, but with the right medical intervention and a whole lot of support, people can lead relatively normal lives.

unnormalised: And let's not forget about the dreaded "acidity." Almost everyone in India has experienced acidity at some point, right? Usually, an antacid like Digene (Rs. 20 for a strip) does the trick, but chronic acidity can be a sign of something more serious, like a peptic ulcer. So, if you're constantly popping antacids, it's probably time to see a gastroenterologist.

unnormalised: Early detection is honestly key. Regular checkups and being aware of your body are crucial. If you notice any persistent changes in your bowel habits, unexplained weight loss, or blood in your stool, please don't ignore it. It's better to be safe than sorry. Many conditions can be managed effectively if caught early.
